keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a pardoned Capitol rioter, has been arrested for allegedly threatening to kill House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan allegedly planned to target Jeffries during a public speech, writing in text messages that he would 'kill him for the future' and that 'even if hated, [Jeffries] must be eliminated.'
Moynihan was sentenced to 21 months in prison in 2023 for breaching the Capitol on January 6, 2021, and was pardoned by President Donald Trump on Trump’s first day back in office.
The incident highlights a broader pattern of political violence in the US, with multiple incidents of threats and attacks against lawmakers in 2025.

Trump's pardon of over 1,000 riot defendants, including Moynihan, has raised significant controversy and prompted renewed scrutiny of the justice system and the treatment of political violence offenders.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a 34-year-old man pardoned by former President Donald Trump for his role in the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot, has been arrested and charged with making a credible death threat against House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Moynihan allegedly planned to target Jeffries during a speech at the Economic Club of New York, writing in text messages that he would 'kill him for the future' and that Jeffries must be eliminated. He was previously sentenced to 21 months in prison in 2023 for breaching Capitol barricades and taking photos of lawmakers. Despite being pardoned, he is now being held in Poughkeepsie and faces new charges, raising concerns about the broader consequences of pardoning political rioters and the rise of political violence in the U.S. This case underscores a troubling trend where former rioters continue to engage in violent threats against elected officials, highlighting the fragility of democratic safety and the need for accountability.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested for allegedly threatening to kill Hakeem Jeffries
